ygData.subject: Re: ACID REST-HTTP
ygData.msgSnippet: Berend, If these are your major objections, I think HTTP/SMTP based transactions look fairly plausible: --On Friday, May 02, 2003 11:45 AM +1200 Berend de Boer

Berend,

If these are your major objections, I think HTTP/SMTP based transactions 
look fairly plausible:

--On Friday, May 02, 2003 11:45 AM +1200 Berend de Boer <berend@...> 
wrote:
> 1. What if an entity I invoke, invokes other entities, and what if
>    they have transactions of their own? Are they in the same
>    transaction? A new transaction? Do they nest?

Presumably, when an entity receives a PREPARE request, it attempts to 
PREPARE any sub-transactions for which it is responsible.  If all those 
PREPAREs are successful, it returns 200 in response to  PREPARE, otherwise 
it returns an error.  If it does anything else, it violates the semantics 
of PREPARE.

> 2. What if an entity I invoke also sends messages? Are they in the
>    transaction as well? In what order?

Presumably in the order of the entities that send them.  How does SOAP 
handle this issue?

> 3. If the client goes down, is the transaction committed? Rolled back?
> 4. Doing two or three phase commit at the client is really innovative
>    I assume... What do we need transaction managers for??

In either protocol, there is no commit until COMMIT.
If you are concerned about client reliability in then set up a durable 
server
to handle the commits.  In the HTTP context, you have a reliable HTTP 
server that posts PREPARE and perhaps COMMIT to a list of URLs supplied in 
a single HTTP request.  In the SMTP context, this is what SMTP servers 
already do for desktop mail clients.  The "unreliable" client sends 
messages to the server and the server is responsible for guaranteeing 
delivery.

>     >> 5. Priorization.
>
>     S> I am not sure what this means, but I suspect you don't want it
>     S> because it violates the End-To-End principle.
>
> Absolutely not! If I want to have certain orders served at higher
> priority, why should software prevent me? If I want paying customers
> to serve at a higher priority at some site, why not?

I assume you are not familiar with the End-To-End (Dumb Network) principle.
Discussion on the internet is quite extensive.  I'd point you to a URL, but 
I'm offline now (try http://isen.com).  The short answer is that 
prioritization is an application layer issue and not a protocol issue.  The 
Internet and even IP-telephony have been quite successful without QoS IP 
routing (some IP packets are more important than others).  Southwest 
Airlines chooses not to prioritize and is doing better than most airlines 
that do (yield-management).

-Alex-
